Award.AwardTitle: Biodiversity and Evolution-Support for U.S. Participants
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports junior U.S. researchers, allowing graduate students and those in early stages of their career to participate in the thematic semester on Biodiversity and Evolution that will be held at the Centre de Recherches Mathematiques (CRM) in Montreal during the second half of 2013. This is part of the more general program of the thematic year on Mathematics of Planet Earth (MPE2013). Five workshops are devoted to (i) random trees, which arise in a wide variety of biological application, (ii) modeling the complex evolutionary dynamics that have shaped the structure of contemporary biodiversity, (iii) models of DNA sequence evolution, (iv) coalescent theory and other genealogical processes, and (v) applications of evolutionary game theory. This grant will allow 25-30 young U.S. researchers to participate in this exciting program.

Understanding the rise and decline of species in interaction with one another and with the environment, not to mention the astonishing variability within species, requires a combination of approaches from distinct scientific disciplines (genomics, ecology, economics, computational biology, mathematical modeling, statistical genetics and bioinformatics). The thematic semester on Biodiversity and Evolution that will be held at the Centre de Recherches Math√©matiques (CRM) in Montreal August-November 2013 will have conferences featuring research on a wide variety of mathematical, statistical, and computational approaches. Participating in conferences will allow 25-30 young researchers to learn about fertile and important research directions, and to interact with the leading researchers in their field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A program on Biodiversity and Evolution was held July-December 2013 at the Centre de rechereches mathematiques in Montreal Canada, as part of a year of activities on the Mathematics of Planet Earth. Its purpose was to bring together researchers from different fields to exchange ideas on the interrelated topics of Biodiversity and Evolution. The goal of the program was to understand how the phenomenal variation of species is maintained through their intricate interactions with each other and with the physical world.

There were five workshops:

  • Random Trees, August 12-16
  • Mathematics for an Evolving Biodiversity, September 16-20
  • Mathematics of DNA Sequence Evolution, September 23-27
  • Coalescent Theory: New Developments and Applications, October 7-11
  • Biodiversity and the Environment: Viability and Dynamic Games Perspective, November 4-8

The proposal supported 29 American scientists to participate in the activities of this special semester. Many of those supported were young researchers, who were exposed to exciting new results and research activities, and had a chance to interact with senior researchers in the informal setting of these small workshop which had several dozen participants compared to the thousands that attend the annual meetings of the American or Canadian Mathematical Societies.

                Much of the conference focused on topics in biology: population genetics, reconstruction of phylogenetic trees, and evolutionary game theory, and on their mathematical counterparts: random trees, branching processes, models for DNA sequence evolution, and the coalescent. The intellectual merit lies in the new research that was stimulated by the program. The exchange of ideas between biologists and applied mathematicians and statisticians, benefitted researchers in these areas and led to new collaborations and interesting new research directions. This exchage of ideas and the impact on young researchers are the most significant broader impacts.
